awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Delivering Confidence and Reliability in Thermal Batteries for Utilities Using an Aggressively Cycled Test Loop for Pumps, Pipes, Joints and Valves
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is focused on developing an energy storage technology that stores electricity as heat and converts its back to electricity whenever needed using thermophotovoltaics (TPV). If successful, the innovation will help transition the United States (US) towards a fully renewable electrical grid. The company is developing one of the only battery technologies able to deliver a cost per unit energy (CPE) for energy storage that will enable the use of renewables by the electrical grid. The innovation will also reduce the production of carbon dioxide (CO2) during the production of electricity and may do the same for transportation and industrial processes. The solution will also support the US’s national defense by increasing the economic manufacturing competitiveness of the US and improving energy security, as well as enabling utility customers to benefit from significant cost savings.

The intellectual merit of this project is focused on the development of a thermal battery system that takes electricity from any source and converts it to extremely high-temperature sensible heat in inexpensive graphite blocks. The innovative feature is its ability to decouple power and energy, enabling any discharge duration between 1-100 hours. Currently, no other system can achieve such great and variable discharge levels at such low cost. The company will build two test rigs to test the pumps, pipes, joints, and valves, and then to test the thermophotovoltaics modules under aggressive thermal cycling conditions. The technical objectives are to: (1) set up the induction furnace system to prescreen materials and components; (2) determine which grades of graphite from large-scale suppliers can meet the specifications of future commercial demonstrations; (3) pre-screen approaches to sealing; (4) quantify the reaction strength of the bonding agent and determine how it can be used in products; and, (5) verify that the system installed seals sufficiently well so that future test loop work will not be delayed. The prototype’s hardware will be scaled-up and the critical components will be stress-tested. The company has already developed a fully-functioning, integrated system at a small scale, 1-10 kilowatt-hour-electric (kWh-e), that works as a proof-of-concept. The reliability of the full-scale hardware in the test loop must be demonstrated prior to building a 1 megawatt-hour-electric (MWh-e) scale demonstration. The company is developing one of the only battery technologies able to deliver a cost per unit energy (CPE) of <$25/kWh-e for energy storage which will enable the full penetration of renewables onto the electrical grid.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to demonstrate the viability of graphite materials and seals for use in a commercial-scale Fourth Power Thermal Battery (FPTB). Prior work in Prof. Asegun Henry's lab at MIT had demonstrated sealing concepts and pipe fittings at a small scale and lower pressure, this SBIR Phase I effort was focused on developing a scaled-up fitting design, that can seal at 100 psi, 2400C, is inexpensive, easy to assemble and can survive many thousands of thermal cycles. Doing so involved (1) the design, procurement, construction and commissioning of a test rig (the Induction Furnace Test Rig) for long-term, high temperature (up to 2400C), cyclic operational testing, as well as (2) the investigation, design, development and testing of a variety of different graphite materials, fittings, seals, and other components in said test rig. Over the course of the project, Fourth Power (FP) achieved a major milestone: the ability to routinely operate the IFTR at temperatures up to 2400C for extended durations. The test rig was built, fully debugged and is now operationalized for long-term reliability testing of graphite components. In parallel with the development of FP's high-temperature test capabilities, FP investigated multiple fitting and seal concepts for joining graphite pipes and components in FP's high-temperature liquid metal system. These efforts were critical in advancing FP's ability to securely and reliably contain liquid metal tin over long durations at temperatures cycling from 1900C to 2400C and pressures up to 100 psi as it flows through the graphite piping between our battery’s subsystems. FP's all-graphite “plumbing system” is a key differentiator of the FPTB to any other thermal battery or grid-scale energy storage system, enabling rapid transfer of thermal energy from heaters (powered by electricity) to the energy storage blocks (ESBs, where the energy is stored for long durations), and from the ESBs to the thermophotovoltaic (TPV) power block (where the heat is converted back to electricity). Using tin as our heat transfer fluid, Fourth Power's energy storage system is able to reach unprecedented power densities while maintaining flexibility to independently scale charge/discharge power and energy capacity, key value propositions for our utility customers. The data and insights gained over the course of this project will inform the subsequent design and testing of a 1 MWh-e demonstration battery, laying the groundwork for future commercial applications of FP's transformative thermal energy storage technology.

 


Last Modified: 02/18/2025
Modified by: Michael George Hvasta
